doc.title: COSCO Shipping Ports Ltd. (1199 HK) First Take: 2Q25 results beat, driven by strong throughput and ASP of European terminals; Buy
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/COSCO Shipping Ports Ltd. 1199.HK First Take 2Q25 results beat driven by strong throughput and ASP of European terminals_2025-08-29

passages.text: Identifying imbalance and inflections across passenger and cargo transportation in Asia Explore >

COSCO Shipping Ports released 1H25 results on Aug 28 after market close, where1H25 net profit of US \(182mn (+31\% \text{YoY} / + 7\% \text{HoH})\) came in above our expectation and market consensus, accounting for \(59\%\) of full- year estimates. This also implies 2Q25 net profit of US \(898mn (+28\% \text{YoY} / + 17\% \text{QoQ})\) , vs. 1Q25 net profit of US \(84mn (+33\% \text{YoY} / - 4\% \text{QoQ})\) , despite a disruption on port throughput from tariff escalation since April. We attribute this strong result mainly to its overseas business, with Piraeus terminal achieving higher storage income and throughput recovery, and CSP Spain and CSP Zeebrugge achieving higher throughput amid alliance reshuffling. The company declared an interim dividend of HK15.1 cents on an unchanged payout ratio of \(40\%\) , which implies \(5.5\%\) annualized dividend yield. Key takeaways include: 1) The profit growth was largely driven by overseas terminals improving to US \(57mn (+187\% \text{YoY})\) in 1H25, while China terminals recorded largely stable results (+1% YoY); 2) For 2025 throughput guidance, the company took reference to Drewry's FY25 global throughput guidance of \(+1.9\%\) YoY, which implies a decline by - \(0.8\%\) YoY in 3Q25 on destocking, while in 4Q25 expects to see further sequential decline; 3) European subsidiaries terminal ASP continue to maintain \(+10\%\) YoY (in local currencies), which management attributed to higher tariff negotiated with shipping lines, storage income and box mix change.

We will host a post- results NDR with the company on Aug 29 (Fri) 3:00- 4:00 PM HKT, both in- person and zoom are available with 1x1 meetings after the group meeting available upon request. Please let us or our sales colleagues know if you are interested.

Geographical breakdown of profit: Profit growth was largely driven by overseas terminals improving to US \(57mn (+187\% \text{YoY})\) in 1H25, while China terminal recorded largely stable results (+1% YoY). Among overseas terminals, Mediterranean lead the growth to US \(37mn (+150\% \text{YoY})\) on higher storage income and throughput recovery at Piraeus terminal, thanks to improving cargo turnover in piling areas and proactive marketing to attract more cargoes, despite

the Red Sea still being closed. Europe also saw strong profit growth to US\(9.4 (+297\% YoY) largely driven by CSP Spain and CSP Zeebrugge terminal on higher throughput amid alliance reshuffling.

Container throughput: Total throughput volume rose \(+6\%\) YoY in 1H25. Among domestic terminals, Pearl River Delta \((+7\% \text{YoY})\) led the throughput growth largely helped by Yantian terminals \((+13\% \text{YoY})\) , which has higher exposure to soft goods and low- ticket items that are less impacted by US tariff hike and benefited from increased calls by Gemini (see our note on HPHT for more details). Overseas terminal throughput saw growth by \(+8\%\) as Zeebrugge \((+45\% \text{YoY})\) and Suez Canal \((+25\% \text{YoY})\) recorded strong growth, while Chancay terminal also began operation from Nov- 24. When asked about 2025 throughput guidance, the company took reference to Drewry's FY25 global throughput guidance of \(+1.9\% \text{YoY}\) . This implies a decline by \(- 0.8\% \text{YoY}\) in 3Q25 on destocking, while 4Q25 is expected to see further sequential decline.

ASP: Cosco port ASP at Chinese subsidiaries fell \(- 2\% \text{YoY}\) (in Rmb) driven by weakness in selected terminals e.g. Nantong due to less cargo volume to US amid US tariff hike. On the other hand, European subsidiaries terminal ASP continued to maintain \(+10\% \text{YoY}\) (in local currencies), which management attributed to higher tariff negotiated with shipping lines, storage income and box mix change.

Cost: Cosco's subsidiary EBIT margin remains largely stable at \(17\%\) despite volume growth (flat vs. 1H24, \(- 1.5\% \text{vs. 2H24}\) ), which we attribute to higher cost contribution from CSP Chancay commencing operation in Nov- 24. On interest expense, the company recorded \(- 14\%\) decline in net interest expense, as average borrowing cost fell to \(4.7\%\) in 1H25 (vs. \(5.43\%\) in 1H24) after loan repayments and optimization of debt- structure.

Capex: The company spent US\(160 on capex in 1H25, among which US\)134mn was spent on PP&E, while US\)26mn was spent on investment. For FY25, the company budgets US\(790mn for total Capex, among which US\)614mn is budgeted to be spent on PP&E for existing terminals including CSP Spain, Peru, Xiamen and Guangzhou Nansha, while the rest is budgeted for equity investment. Currently, the company noted acquisitions of equity stakes in Thai Laemchabang Terminal (TLT) and Hutchison Laemchabang Terminal (HLT) are the only ongoing acquisitions, which is expected to be completed by Sep- 25.
Cosco Shipping Ports operates 37 ports worldwide and is mainly engaged in container leasing, container terminal operations, logistics and container manufacturing. We see

sufficient upside potential on growth driven by 1) Continued port tariff hikes to pass on inflation to shipping liners, 2) Volume growth driven by the parentco, especially during a shipping downcycle, and 3) Cveases expansion to drive long-term growth. We are Buy rated with the stock trading at added yield above mid-cycle, which we believe is inexpensive as we expect its D to increase further even during a shipping downcycle given its defensive biness m and continued record price hikes.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.
